abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project for Egypt were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project suitability was likely, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            SAL came at a time when the Government's reforms in
            support of private sector development and away from public
            sector were well underway. The demise of the Soviet bloc
            leading to the decline of central planning strategies and
            the ascendance of free market economies provided an extra
            impetus to the Egyptian reforms. The magnitude of the
            macroeconomic imbalances and the distortions in the
            incentive system warranted a comprehensive approach to
            reform. The Government felt that strong action was needed
            and demonstrated a commitment to implement such action. The
            reforms led to substantial macroeconomic stabilization of
            the economy. On the other hand, the deeper reforms under the
            EFF and the SAMP encouraged opposition from vested interest
            groups, which prompted the Government to pursue a slower
            reform pace. The Government received very substantial
            assistance from the Bank and the donor community for
            implementing its economic reform program, both in terms of
            financial support and technical advice. The close working
            relationship with the Government contributed to the
            satisfactory implementation of a very ambitious
            stabilization and structural adjustment program.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Loan Project
            (SAL) will pursue three broad objectives: stabilization;
            structural reform towards the strengthening of a market
            economy to improve resource allocation and restore
            sustainable growth; and the construction of a more adequate
            social safety net to mitigate the effects of the economic
            reforms on the poor. It emphasizes the structural reforms
            needed to improve resource allocation and growth. In
            addition to supporting an adequate medium-term macroeconomic
            framework and financing plan, it supports the initiation of
            reforms in the public sector, including privatization. It
            also supports the Government's resolve to reduce
            distortion in both prices and the overall incentive
            environment, to be pursued through the liberalization of
            price, trade, production and investment controls.
